paragraphs.text:
%md

## Spark Core (RDDs) and Spark SQL Module
#### Analyzing a Text File

**Level**: Beginner
**Language**: Python
**Requirements**: 
- [HDP 2.5](http://hortonworks.com/products/sandbox/) (or later) or [HDCloud](https://hortonworks.github.io/hdp-aws/)
- Spark 2.x

**Author**: Robert Hryniewicz
**Twitter**: @RobH8z

**#FutureOfData**

result.msg:
Spark Core (RDDs) and Spark SQL Module

Analyzing a Text File

Level: Beginner
Language: Python
Requirements:

  • HDP 2.5 (or later) or HDCloud
  • Spark 2.x

Author: Robert Hryniewicz
Twitter: @RobH8z

#FutureOfData

paragraphs.text:
%md
This lab consists of two parts. In each section you will perform a basic Word Count.
#
In **Part 1**, we will introduce **RDDs**, Spark's primary low-level abstraction, and several core concepts.
In **Part 2**, we will introduce **DataFrames**, a higher-level abstraction than RDDs, along with Spark SQL Module allowing you to use SQL statements to query a temporary view.

result.msg:
This lab consists of two parts. In each section you will perform a basic Word Count.

In Part 1, we will introduce RDDs, Spark's primary low-level abstraction, and several core concepts.
In Part 2, we will introduce DataFrames, a higher-level abstraction than RDDs, along with Spark SQL Module allowing you to use SQL statements to query a temporary view.

paragraphs.title: Introduction

paragraphs.text:
%md
At the core of Spark is the notion of a Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD), which is an immutable and fault-tolerant collection of objects that is partitioned and distributed across multiple physical nodes on a cluster and they run in parallel.
#
Typically, RDDs are instantiated by loading data from a shared filesystem, HDFS, HBase, or any data source offering a Hadoop InputFormat on a YARN cluster.
#
Once an RDD is instantiated, you can apply a **[series of operations](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#rdd-operations)**.
#
All operations fall into one of two types: **[Transformations](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#transformations)** or **[Actions](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#actions)**. 
#
Transformation operations, as the name suggests, create new datasets from an existing RDD and build out the processing Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) that can then be applied on the partitioned dataset across the YARN cluster. An Action operation, on the other hand, executes DAG and returns a value.
#
In this lab we will use the following **[Transformations](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#transformations)**:
- map(func)
- filter(func)
- flatMap(func)
- reduceByKey(func)

and **[Actions](https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/programming-guide.html#actions)**:

- collect()
- count()
- take()
- takeOrdered(n, [ordering])
- countByKey()

A typical Spark application has the following four phases:
1. Instantiate Input RDDs
2. Transform RDDs
3. Persist Intermediate RDDs
4. Take Action on RDDs

result.msg:
At the core of Spark is the notion of a Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD), which is an immutable and fault-tolerant collection of objects that is partitioned and distributed across multiple physical nodes on a cluster and they run in parallel.

Typically, RDDs are instantiated by loading data from a shared filesystem, HDFS, HBase, or any data source offering a Hadoop InputFormat on a YARN cluster.

Once an RDD is instantiated, you can apply a series of operations.

All operations fall into one of two types: Transformations or Actions.

Transformation operations, as the name suggests, create new datasets from an existing RDD and build out the processing Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) that can then be applied on the partitioned dataset across the YARN cluster. An Action operation, on the other hand, executes DAG and returns a value.

In this lab we will use the following Transformations:

  • map(func)
  • filter(func)
  • flatMap(func)
  • reduceByKey(func)

and Actions:

  • collect()
  • count()
  • take()
  • takeOrdered(n, [ordering])
  • countByKey()

A typical Spark application has the following four phases:

  1. Instantiate Input RDDs
  2. Transform RDDs
  3. Persist Intermediate RDDs
  4. Take Action on RDDs

paragraphs.text:
%md 

## Part 1
#### Introduction to RDDs (Spark Core) with Word Count example

result.msg:
Part 1

Introduction to RDDs (Spark Core) with Word Count example

paragraphs.text:
%md
In this section you will perform a basic word count with RDDs.
#
You will download external text data file to your sandbox. Then you will perform lexical analysis, or tokenization, by breaking up text into words/tokens.
The list of tokens then becomes an input for further processing to this and following sections.
#
By the end of this section you should have learned how to perform low-level transformations and actions with Spark RDDs and lambda expressions.

result.msg:
In this section you will perform a basic word count with RDDs.

You will download external text data file to your sandbox. Then you will perform lexical analysis, or tokenization, by breaking up text into words/tokens.
The list of tokens then becomes an input for further processing to this and following sections.

By the end of this section you should have learned how to perform low-level transformations and actions with Spark RDDs and lambda expressions.

paragraphs.text:
%md

In the following paragraphs we are going to execute Spark code, run shell commands to download and move files, run sql queries etc. Each paragraph will start with `%` followed by an interpreter name, e.g. `%pyspark` for a Spark Python interpreter. Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc. This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughtout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

- `%pyspark` - Spark Python interpreter to run Spark code written in Python
- `%spark` - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala (we'll only use to check Spark version)
- `%sql` - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)
- `%sh` - Shell interpreter to run shell commands
- `%angular` - Angular interpreter to run Angular and HTML code
- `%md` - Markdown for displaying formatted text, links, and images

Note: The **default interpreter**, if none is specified, is the `%spark` interpreter.

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this [link](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.5.6-incubating/manual/interpreters.html).

Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc. This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughtout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

  • %pyspark - Spark Python interpreter to run Spark code written in Python
  • %spark - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala (we'll only use to check Spark version)
  • %sql - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)

Note: The default interpreter, if none is specified, is the %spark interpreter.

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this link.

paragraphs.text:
%sh

#  Remove old dataset file if already exists in local /tmp directory
if [ -e /tmp/nifi.txt ]
then
    rm -f /tmp/nifi.txt
fi

#fi

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roberthryniewicz/datasets/master/About-Apache-NiFi.txt -O /tmp/nifi.txt

# TODO Enable

#hadoop fs -put nifi.txt /tmp

paragraphs.text:
%md
Note that the main entry point (starting with Spark 2.x) is `spark` (for SparkSession) which is automatically initialized in Zeppelin.

result.msg: Note that the main entry point (starting with Spark 2.x) is spark (for SparkSession) which is automatically initialized in Zeppelin.

paragraphs.title: Read Text File from HDFS and Preview its Contents
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Parallelize text file using pre-initialized Spark context (sc)
lines = spark.sparkContext.textFile("/tmp/nifi.txt")

# Take a look at a few lines with a take() action.
print lines.take(10)

result.msg: [u'Apache NiFi Overview ', u'Team dev@nifi.apache.org ', u'', u'What is Apache NiFi? Put simply NiFi was built to automate the flow of data between systems. While the term dataflow is used in a variety of contexts, we\u2019ll use it here to mean the automated and managed flow of information between systems. This problem space has been around ever since enterprises had more than one system, where some of the systems created data and some of the systems consumed data. The problems and solution patterns that emerged have been discussed and articulated extensively. A comprehensive and readily consumed form is found in the Enterprise Integration Patterns [eip]. ', u'', u'Some of the high-level challenges of dataflow include: ', u'', u'Systems fail ', u'Networks fail, disks fail, software crashes, people make mistakes. ', u'']

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the next paragraphs we will start using Python lambda (or anonymous) functions. If you're unfamiliar with lambda expressions, 
review **[Python Lambda Expressions](https://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/controlflow.html#lambda-expressions)** before proceeding.

result.msg:
In the next paragraphs we will start using Python lambda (or anonymous) functions. If you're unfamiliar with lambda expressions,
review Python Lambda Expressions before proceeding.

paragraphs.title: Extract All Words from the Document
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Here we're tokenizing our text file by using the split() function. Each original line of text is split into words or tokens on a single space.
#  Also, since each line of the original text occupies a seperate bucket in the array, we need to use
#  a flatMap() transformation to flatten all buckets into a asingle/flat array of tokens.

words = lines.flatMap(lambda line: line.split(" "))

%md
Note that after you click 'play' in the paragraph above "nothing" appears to happen.
#
That's because `flatMap()` is a transformation and all transformations in Spark are lazy, in that they do not compute their results right away. Instead, they just remember the transformations applied to some base dataset (e.g. a file). The transformations are only computed when an action requires a result to be returned to the driver program. This design enables Spark to run more efficiently – for example, we can realize that a dataset created through map will be used in a reduce and return only the result of the reduce to the driver, rather than the larger mapped dataset.
#
By default, each transformed RDD may be recomputed each time you run an action on it. However, you may also persist an RDD in memory using the persist (or cache) method, in which case Spark will keep the elements around on the cluster for much faster access the next time you query it. There is also support for persisting RDDs on disk, or replicated across multiple nodes.

result.msg:
Note that after you click 'play' in the paragraph above “nothing” appears to happen.

That's because flatMap() is a transformation and all transformations in Spark are lazy, in that they do not compute their results right away. Instead, they just remember the transformations applied to some base dataset (e.g. a file). The transformations are only computed when an action requires a result to be returned to the driver program. This design enables Spark to run more efficiently – for example, we can realize that a dataset created through map will be used in a reduce and return only the result of the reduce to the driver, rather than the larger mapped dataset.

By default, each transformed RDD may be recomputed each time you run an action on it. However, you may also persist an RDD in memory using the persist (or cache) method, in which case Spark will keep the elements around on the cluster for much faster access the next time you query it. There is also support for persisting RDDs on disk, or replicated across multiple nodes.

paragraphs.title: Take a look at first 100 words
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
print words.take(100)   # we're using a take(n) action

# Output: As you can see, each word occupies a distinc array bucket.

paragraphs.title: Remove Empty Words
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

wordsFiltered = words.filter(lambda w: len(w) > 0)

paragraphs.title: Get Total Number of Words
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

print wordsFiltered.count()     # using a count() action

%md
#### Word Counts

Let's see what are the most popular words by performing a word count using `map()` and `reduceByKey()` transformations to create tuples of type (word, count).

result.msg:
Word Counts

Let's see what are the most popular words by performing a word count using map() and reduceByKey() transformations to create tuples of type (word, count).

paragraphs.title: Word count with a RDD
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

wordCounts = wordsFiltered.map(lambda word: (word, 1)).reduceByKey(lambda a,b: a+b)

%md
#### View Word Count Tuples
Now let's take a look at top 100 words in descending order with a `takeOrdered()` action.

result.msg:
View Word Count Tuples

Now let's take a look at top 100 words in descending order with a takeOrdered() action.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
print wordCounts.takeOrdered(100, lambda (w,c): -c)

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Filter out infrequent words
We'll use `filter()` transformation to filter out words that occur less than five times.

result.msg:
Filter out infrequent words

We'll use filter() transformation to filter out words that occur less than five times.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

filteredWordCounts = wordCounts.filter(lambda (w,c): c >= 5)

print filteredWordCounts.collect()   # we're using a collect() action to pull everything back to the Spark driver

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now let's use `countByKey()` action for another way of returning a word count.

result.msg: Now let's use countByKey() action for another way of returning a word count.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

result =  words.map(lambda w: (w,1)).countByKey()

# Print type of data structure
print type(result)

result.msg: <type 'collections.defaultdict'>

paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note** that the **result** is an **unordered dictionary of type {word, count}**.
Since this is a small set we can apply a simple (non-parallelizeable) python built-in function.

result.msg:
Note that the result is an unordered dictionary of type {word, count}.
Since this is a small set we can apply a simple (non-parallelizeable) python built-in function.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Take a look at first 20 items in our dictionary.

result.msg: Take a look at first 20 items in our dictionary.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Print first 20 items
print result.items()[0:20]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Apply a python `sorted()` function on the **result** dictionary values.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
import operator

# Sort in descending order
sortedResult = sorted(result.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1), reverse=True)

# Print top 20 items
print sortedResult[0:20]

%md
## Part 2
#### Introduction to DataFrames and SQL APIs (Spark SQL Module)

result.msg:
Part 2

Introduction to DataFrames and SQL APIs (Spark SQL Module)

paragraphs.text:
%md
In this section we will cover the concept of a DataFrame. You will convert RDDs from a previous section and then use higher level 
operations to demonstrate a different way of counting words. Then you will register a temporary table and perform a word count by 
executing a SQL query on that table.
#
By the end of the section you will have learned higher-level Spark abstractions that hide lower-level details, speed up prototyping and execution.

result.msg:
In this section we will cover the concept of a DataFrame. You will convert RDDs from a previous section and then use higher level
operations to demonstrate a different way of counting words. Then you will register a temporary table and perform a word count by
executing a SQL query on that table.

By the end of the section you will have learned higher-level Spark abstractions that hide lower-level details, speed up prototyping and execution.

paragraphs.title: DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. [See SparkSQL docs for more info](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html#dataframes).

result.msg: A DataFrame is a distributed collection of data organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. See SparkSQL docs for more info.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Transform your RDD into a DataFrame and perform DataFrame specific operations.

result.msg: Transform your RDD into a DataFrame and perform DataFrame specific operations.

paragraphs.title: Word Count with a DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# First, let's transform our RDD to a DataFrame.
# We will use a Row to define column names.
wordsCounts = (filteredWordCounts.map(lambda (w, c): 
                Row(word=w,
                    count=c))
                .toDF())

# Print schema
wordsCounts.printSchema()

# Output: As you can see, the count and word types have been inferred without having to explicitly define long and string types respectively.

result.msg:
root
 |-- count: long (nullable = true)
 |-- word: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.title: Show top 20 rows
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Show top 20 rows
wordsCounts.show()

paragraphs.title: Register a Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

wordsCountsDF.registerTempTable("wordcounts")

%md
Now we can query the temporary `wordcounts` table with a SQL statement.

result.msg: Now we can query the temporary wordcounts table with a SQL statement.

paragraphs.text:
%md
To execute a SparkSQL query we prepend a block of SQL code with a `%sql` line.

result.msg: To execute a SparkSQL query we prepend a block of SQL code with a %sql line.

paragraphs.text:
%sql

-- Display word counts in descending order
SELECT word, count FROM wordcounts ORDER BY count DESC

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now let's take a step back and perform a word count with SQL

result.msg: Now let's take a step back and perform a word count with SQL

paragraphs.title: Convert RDD to a DataFrame and Register a New Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Convert wordsFiltered RDD to a Data Frame
words = wordsFiltered.map(lambda w: Row(word=w, count=1)).toDF()

paragraphs.title: Use DataFrame Specific Functions to Determine Word Counts
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

(words.groupBy("word")
        .sum()
        .orderBy("sum(count)", ascending=0)
        .limit(10).show())

paragraphs.title: Register as Temp Table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Register as Temp Table
words.registerTempTable("words")

paragraphs.title: Word Count using SQL
paragraphs.text:
%md

Now let's do a word count using a SQL statement against the `words` table and order the results in a descending order by count.

result.msg: Now let's do a word count using a SQL statement against the words table and order the results in a descending order by count.

paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT word, count(*) as count FROM words GROUP BY word ORDER BY count DESC LIMIT 10

result.msg:
word	count
the	110
of	94
and	89
to	84
is	62
a	60
NiFi	41
as	32
The	28
be	26

paragraphs.title: The End
paragraphs.text:
%md
You've reached the end of this lab! We hope you've been able to successfully complete all the sections and learned a thing or two about Apache Spark: low-level RDD transformations and actions as well as higher-level DataFrame and SQL APIs.

result.msg: You've reached the end of this lab! We hope you've been able to successfully complete all the sections and learned a thing or two about Apache Spark: low-level RDD transformations and actions as well as higher-level DataFrame and SQL APIs.

paragraphs.text:
%md

We hope you've enjoyed this brief intro to Apache Spark. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hadoop Summit: Slides & Videos](http://hadoopsummit.org/san-jose/agenda/) - a collection of presentations on Spark, Hadoop, and other Big Data related topics.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.5.0/bk_spark-component-guide/content/ch_developing-spark-apps.html) - official Spark documentation.
5. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.5.0/bk_zeppelin-component-guide/content/ch_using_zeppelin.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
